12  Appendix 5 
 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government requested ADB to consider financing for the proposed Solid Waste 
Management Sector Project. The project will help improve the quality of urban environmental 
conditions and achieve the environmental targets of the Philippines Development Plan (PDP). 
Consultant support is required for preparing a feasibility study to develop the sector loan project 
and  confirming  its  viability.  The  project  is  in  line  with  the  provisions  of  the  ADB  Country 
Partnership Strategy 2011–2016, which will extend assistance to this key subsector expected to 
receive priority under Philippine Development Plan 2011–2016. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The  ensuing  Project  will  comprise  the  following  outputs:  Output  1:  solid  waste 
management plans of selected local government units (LGUs) prepared; Output 2: investment 
projects  for  priority  solid  waste  management  facilities  completed;  and  Output  3:  project 
management and institutional capacity improved. 
 
3.  The TA will be implemented in 2 phases, which may partly overlap. The first phase will 
prepare  a  short-list  of  three  (3)  LGUs  suitable  for  participation  and  develop  solid  waste 
management plans for them.1 The second phase will (i) prepare subproject appraisal reports 
(SPARs)  for  the  short-listed  LGUs  prioritizing  components  suggested  by  the  solid  waste 
management plans; 2 (ii) determine the viability of the proposed investments through feasibility 
studies and preliminary design; and (iii) prepare an institutional capacity development program. 
The major outputs and activities of the TA are summarized in Table A5.1.

opportunities for private sector participation.

reduction (e.g. power generation, carbon credits, etc.); (g) landfill mining; (h) waste to energy; and (i) construction 
of new sanitary landfills, particularly regional landfills serving more than one local government.

14  Appendix 5 
 
D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  Consultants will be engaged through a firm. The TA will require 4 positions and 18 
person-months (pm) of international consulting services, and 11 positions and 41 pm of national 
consulting  services.  ADB  will  select  and  engage  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The quality-and cost-
based  selection  method  (quality–cost  ratio  of  90:10),  using  simplified  technical  proposal 
procedures, will be followed.

6.  The outline terms of reference for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paras. 27 to 34. 
 
7.  Solid  waste  management  specialist  (2  international  11  pm,  3  national  13  pm). 
Consultants will provide assessment of the solid waste management sector in the country, 
including technical aspects, environment, demand and institutional and financial aspects. They 
will assist in short-listing 3 LGUs for subproject appraisal reports, and will prepare a feasibility 
study for processing of the ensuing sector loan. One of the international specialists will be the 
team leader responsible for the overall outcome of the PPTA. The consultants will arrange at 
least 3 workshops and seminars to increase stakeholders' participation in the project design and 
selection of investment proposals, and to ensure appropriate dissemination of project results. 
 
8.  Financial / economic specialist (international 4 pm, national 4 pm). The experts will (i) 
provide a detailed financial and economic analysis of the each subproject and the overall 
project; (ii)  carry  out  a  financial  management  assessment  and  outline  the funds flow  and 
disbursement  mechanisms;  (iii)  assess  the  borrowing  capacity  of  the  participating  local 
governments; (iv) prepare financial projections and analysis; (v) calculate required solid waste 
management tariffs and confirm their affordability; (vi) investigate innovative financing schemes.  
 
9.  Institutional development (international 3 pm, national 4 pm). The consultants will 
prepare an institutional and capacity assessment for the entire solid waste management chain 
from  collection  to  disposal,  assess  gaps  and  develop  mitigating  capacity  development 
programs.  
 
10.  Social development and gender (national 4 pm). The expert will provide a detailed 
social and gender analysis, and develop community development and awareness programs. 
They  will  conduct  household  surveys  and  focus  group  discussions  to  confirm  the  social 
acceptability and viability of the project.  Issues and concerns regarding waste pickers (an 
informal labor group; mainly women and children) will be assessed; they form an important 
group of stakeholders.

Appendix 5  15 
 
11.  Resettlement and indigenous peoples (national 4 pm). The specialist will ensure that 
ADB’s safeguard requirements for involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples are properly 
addressed, and will prepare related documents for the project.  
 
12.  Development Communications Specialist (national 3 pm). The expert will undertake a 
detailed  communication  needs  assessment  of  the  project  and  prepare  a  strategic 
communication program both for project design and implementation. The consultant will work 
closely with the social development specialist in the communication aspects of the tasks related 
to this program. 
 
13.  Environment (national 4 pm). The consultant will ensure that the environmental impacts 
of the project are addressed in line with ADB and national requirements. They will prepare 
environmental  safeguard  documents  as  applicable  including  but  not  limited  to  initial 
environmental examination, environmental impact assessment, and environmental management 
plans.  An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  (EARF),  and  environmental 
assessment reports of the core subprojects will be prepared. 
 
14.  Legal  (national  2  pm).  The  legal  specialist  will  review  the  legal  and  regulatory 
framework, address the legal aspects of the project, and advise LGUs on drafting of SWM 
related ordinances required by the project as applicable.  
 
15.  Procurement  (national  3  pm).  The  expert  will  carry  out  a  procurement  capacity 
assessment  of  the  selected  LGUs  and  national  agencies  as  applicable  and  prepare 
procurement plans and implementation schedules for the individual subprojects and the overall 
project.  He  will  assess  the  capacity  of  government  procurement  agents  and  explore 
opportunities for involving them during project implementation. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The executing agency (EA) for the PPTA will be Department of Environment and Natural 
Resources (DENR), which has an established project management unit (PMU) that will be 
responsible for organizing the technical and administrative aspects of the PPTA, and day-to-day 
decisions affecting its implementation. The PMU will include suitably qualified and experienced 
counterpart staff to work alongside the PPTA consultants. The PPTA consultant will provide full 
support to the head of the PMU and will work in close collaboration with the counterpart team. 
The  EA  will  provide  the  consultant  with  suitable  office  space,  office  furniture  (including  a 
sufficient  number  of  standard  desks,  chairs,  shelves,  and  closets),  lighting,  electricity,  air 
conditioning, and access to phone lines. 
 
17.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, amended from time to time). The consultants 
may procure equipment through shopping in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, amended from time to time). Upon completion of the TA, equipment procured under the 
TA will be transferred to the EA. The TA is expected to commence on 1 September 2012 and to 
be completed by 30 April 2013. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is 
listed in Table A5.4. 
 
Table 5.4: Proposed Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date 
TA commencement  September 2012 
Inception report  October 2012 
Interim report  December 2012 
Draft final report  March 2013 
Final report  April 2013 
Financial closure  July  2013 
 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
